caption: Place de la Concorde is one of the most beautiful squares in Paris, known for its stunning design and historical landmarks like the Egyptian obelisk and grand fountains. It's an ideal spot for strolling and taking pictures, with breathtaking views of the Seine River and the Tuileries Gardens. You can also catch a glimpse of the Eiffel Tower from here, making it a must-visit for tourists. However, it can get crowded at times, so visiting in the early morning or evening is recommended. The area is clean, well-organized, and offers an authentic Parisian atmosphere. Don't miss it when you're in Paris!

Another amazing mega plaza with more mega structures in the center of Paris. This one has a very very dark past as it's where the guillotines were placed. The vibe here is egyptian as the biggest thing is an Egyptian Obelisk that has been donated to France centuries ago. It's totally amazing getting to see this in person.
Must visit attraction in Paris. Once you get down here, you can walk all the way to Louvre, which is good.  Or walk from Louvre to here.

Such an inspiring place with such a dark past. Site of the infamous guillotine where most of the despised gentry met their end during the Revolution. Now a tourist attraction and events venue. Ornate fountains surround the Obelisk that is adorned with Egyptian Hieroglyphics. Ironically the Place can be seen in direct line from the original Palace of the Louvre. I was unable to get closer as the site was being restored after the Olympics.

There are really really beautiful views from here depending on the time and type of day you come here. Super early in the morning it's really beautiful especially with a nice sunrise. It  an be chaotic at other times which isn't as pleasant.

This is an open space with significant history and amazing structures and fountains. This is in between the arc de triomphe (~2 Km) and Louvre museum (~2 km). I recommend one to start at Arc de Triomphe very early and walk from there to Place de la Concorde; as the street leading to this place has all these Fashion houses more importantly, the photographs are going to be awesome. I can spot only south Asians and Asians at this hour as we know we can have a look at the things very peacefully and they will be the least crowded. This may be with greater historic significance but one can fit the visit to this place a few hours before your visit to Louvre Museum. What I did is that my Louvre museum was at 9 AM so I visited this place at 7:30. There is a metro or subway that leads directly to this place; perhaps a few minutes walk. Once you have looked at this place walk all the way through the gardens leading to Louvre museum. There are no information boards or anything indicating the importance of this place that‚Äôs bad someone should look into this soon.
A very beautiful monument and everyone should visit. The view around is phenomenal, you could see the Eiffel tower, Champs-Elys√©es, Arc d√© Triomphe and Jardin de Tuileries.

Place de la Concorde was impressively transformed into an urban sports complex for the Olympics. This historic square as a vibrant sports hub was a sight to see, with the skate park standing out. It was fascinating to see such a classic Parisian landmark seamlessly adapted for contemporary sports and activities -- a fresh and dynamic experience.
One Paris‚Äô busy square. Has some decorated fountains and statues. Great views of the square and the Eiffel Tower is possible from Tuileries Garden‚Äô elevated section.

Place de la Concorde is one of the most breathtaking and historically significant squares in Paris, and a visit here is an absolute delight. Nestled between the Tuileries Garden and the start of the Champs-√âlys√©es, its central location makes it a convenient stop for anyone exploring the heart of the city. Whether you‚Äôre strolling through Paris or planning a structured sightseeing itinerary, this majestic square offers something for everyone.  The history of Place de la Concorde is as grand as its size. Originally named Place Louis XV, it later became infamous as the site of the guillotine during the French Revolution. The square bore witness to some of the most tumultuous moments in French history, including the execution of King Louis XVI and Queen Marie Antoinette. Today, it stands as a symbol of unity and peace, as its name suggests, and a tribute to Paris‚Äôs rich cultural legacy.  The highlight of the square is undoubtedly the magnificent Obelisk of Luxor, a 3,300-year-old Egyptian artifact gifted to France in the 19th century. Standing tall at the center of the square, the obelisk is flanked by two beautiful fountains: the Fountain of the Seas and the Fountain of the Rivers, both adorned with exquisite sculptures. The artistry and craftsmanship of these features are truly mesmerizing, making them a perfect backdrop for photographs.  Reaching Place de la Concorde is incredibly easy. The Concorde metro station, served by lines 1, 8, and 12, places you right at the square. For walkers, the location is ideal, as it connects seamlessly with other iconic attractions. You can take a leisurely walk from the Louvre through the Tuileries Garden or continue from here to the Arc de Triomphe via the Champs-√âlys√©es.  What makes Place de la Concorde truly magical is its atmosphere and views. From this open square, you can admire a 360-degree panorama of Paris. The Eiffel Tower peeks from the distance, the grandeur of the Madeleine Church beckons, and the Seine glimmers nearby. Whether you visit during the day or when the city lights shine at night, the square‚Äôs elegance and charm never fail to amaze.  In summary, Place de la Concorde is a harmonious blend of history, art, and beauty. Its accessibility, historical significance, and stunning vistas make it an unmissable highlight of any trip to Paris. It‚Äôs a place where the city‚Äôs past and present come together in perfect harmony.
A remarkable square. Very large open space. Safe at night. You can see the Eiffel tower from here. You can also see straight down the Champs Elysees towards the Arc de Triomphe.

Happy accident.   Ended up at the Place de la Concorde On the metro on our way to the Maille Mustard boutique.   So happy we did.  Ran into this beautiful ChristmasüéÖüèºüéÑ market filled with vendors selling art, crafts and my much loved Vin Chaud (mulled wine).   If you have time while in Paris don‚Äôt hesitate.  You have a gorgeous view of the Eiffel Tower and the decorations are beautiful.  You won‚Äôt regret it.
Wonderful and beautiful, you can sail through history by seeing it and the writings engraved on it

Place de la Concorde, the largest public square in Paris, is home to the oldest monument in the city - a 3,300-year-old Egyptian obelisk[5][9]. This 23-meter-high granite monolith, originally from the Luxor Temple, was gifted to France by Egypt in 1829 and erected in the square in 1836[2][9]. It stands as a silent witness to both ancient history and the square's tumultuous past, including its role as the site of over 1,100 executions during the French Revolution, among them King Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette[3]. Very cool site to see, the fountains and obelisk are beautiful and there is SO much history here.
Located at the bottom of the Tuileries, is this impressive big square, the square is currently under going refurbishment, however, it does not detract from the beauty of the area.

Place de la Concorde is one of Paris‚Äôs most historic and impressive squares, located between the Champs-√âlys√©es and the Tuileries Garden. It‚Äôs known for its grandeur, with the iconic Egyptian obelisk standing at its center, surrounded by beautiful fountains and statues. The square offers stunning views of major Paris landmarks, including the Eiffel Tower and the Arc de Triomphe. Its rich history and central location make it a must-visit for anyone exploring the city, offering a perfect blend of French history, architecture, and charm.
Wonderful experience shared with my son. Everyone should share Paris with someone they love.
Impressive place with a lot of history. Beautiful fountains and you can definitely take some nice pictures here
It was ok. Nothim much to see here. You can see the main street that stratches all the way to Arc.
Liked to chill out at the square. There was Christmas market and so much fun to spend time here.

There was a Christmas marked which i thought was some how funny since the french revolutions decapitation of the bourbon happend there back in the day. It is nice but way to crowded for a Christmas marked

I visited this place during the Christmas holidays, we walked to this place from our hotel in the evening, the Obelisk lights up at night, it looked beautiful!!! You can walk around and also see the Eiffel Tower and the Arc de triumph. A good place to take pictures and safe for kids and family.
The Egyptian Stella was amazing and so beautiful fountain. You even got a Bice view of the Eiffel Tower
Beautiful place highly recommend going there and enjoying the sunrise
A great spot to visit. It's now half pedestrianised so you don't need to get run over to get a good pic5.
Nice place but I prefer to see in perspective from the street behind to the end to this place

A notable square in Paris, situated at the eastern end of the Champs-√âlys√©es and is known for its iconic Egyptian obelisk, fountains, and historical significance. The square has witnessed numerous pivotal events in French history, including the execution of King Louis XVI during the French Revolution, offering splendid views of landmarks.

The Eiffel Tower was surrounded with metallic panels because it was being repainted. We couldn‚Äôt see the famous obelisk that is more than 3000 years old, because it‚Äôs surrounded by scaffolding. Don‚Äôt know how long it will take to be able to see it again.
Beautifully decorated during the Christmas holidays. Must visit places in Paris during Christmas
The largest square of Paris with Fontaines de la Concorde.
Beautiful area where street performers hangout and party
Must see. The view from Place de la Concorde to l‚ÄôArc de Trionphe is awesome

Did you know some statue there was given because some Louis got over his illness. All I hear is "hey where were you?".. sounds unfair.. the spikey thing is cool, made in Egypt so not real Parisian. Thank you monsieur who deciphered the hieroglyphics in Egypt. Would not have been the same without you.
Must come during the Rugby World Cup. Lovely atmosphere and busy like crazy when France is playing, and the entrance is free.  Beer, hot dog, sausage, hamburger and fries are also reasonably priced.

I visited here during the Rugby World Cup 2023. I watched a few rugby games here and the atmosphere was electric. Easy to navigate your way here and many possibilities to buy something to eat or drink. It is also nearby other iconic landmarks as well as local restaurants and pubs.
Just magnificent. Yes plenty of cars but a wonderful atmosphere.

Giant plaza which is unfortunately partially obstructed by the fenced off area, being prepared for the 2024 summer Olympics. There are two great fountains in the plaza and a giant obelisk from the city of Luxor, Egypt that dates back over 2000 years. You can also get good views of the Arc de Triomphe and Eiffel Tower from this plaza.
